name: The Fairmont Hotel Macdonald

reviews.text: We had a very enjoyable stay at the Fairmont Hotel Macdonald in late March 2008. for four days. We were a foursome, my husband and I plus my teenage daughter and her friend. Why Edmonton in March? The visit West Edmonton Mall, of course, but we didn’t want to stay at the Mall’s hotel (too much!)
reviews.title: Enjoyable stay at Fairmont Hotel Macdonald

likes.liked: — Great staff, lovely older chateau type hotel, wonderful location - downtown but you get to nature fast
likes.disliked: — Executive room not quite laid out for the family purpose we had - another choice next time

reviews.title: Wonderful
reviews.text: We really liked this lovely older “chateau” style hotel. It has great charm and lots of splendid carved wood, and is well updated. Décor in white and cream, in the halls and room, was modern and relaxing, and the restaurant and lounge were flooded with light by grand windows. Elevators were old-fashioned looking but quick and smooth in operation, and bathrooms were luxurious and up to date. For me, the citrus shampoos and soaps used in the Fairmont chain, are a real treat.

The location of this hotel is really good – it’s right downtown, close to major buildings, but it sits at the top of an escarpment over the river, which has spectacular views and surprisingly good access to nature. Within five minutes out the hotel door you are finding your way down to landscaped pedestrian/biking-only trails. These lead to a walkway-bridge across the river and a series of nicely-treed parks on the other side. In the hotel itself, there’s a nice fitness facility with a pleasant pool and squash courts we made good use of.
reviews.title: Beautiful hotel

reviews.title: what an experience
reviews.text: A word on the room. We took an executive suite with a king bed for the adults, and a separate “office” type room with pull-out bed for the kids. The suite was large and well-equipped, with a French door between the two rooms; I was really surprised at how good this door was at blocking the sound of the kids’ TV. For a real executive plus spouse, the layout of the rooms would have been great. However, for a family, I’d look for something different next time. The room the kids were using had no cupboards, which made for clothes strewn all over (oh well, you’d get this anyway) and they had to go thru our bedroom to get to the bathroom. My daughter also complained a bit about the pull-out bed, but she’s used to a very soft (like, ghastly soft) bed at home. Our king bed was just perfect; great for my bad back – firm but cushy.

We stayed here on our way to the Rockies. The hotel has a beautiful exterior-didn't see anyplace that looked near as regal driving through Edmonton. We stayed here with our young children and thus got a suite(can't remember-think it was called a jr suite. I called ahead specifically to confirm that the bedroom was separated from the living area by a door/wall and was assured it was. To our unhappy surprise, when we checked in our room (although it had a huge living room area) was not closed off from the bedroom-there was just a wide open arch. Since it was late and our kids were exhausted we kept the room. When I asked about my previous assurance I was told that some rooms do have a door but they were "out of them" for the night. I will say that the next day they moved us to a nearby suite that had glass french doors with sheer curtains that closed-much better. The rooms are elegantly furnished and our bed was very comfortable. The sleeper sofa in the first room,however,was very uncomfortable. Our small kids complained and we wound up padding it with a blanket-not what we expected for the price we were paying. Ate dinner at the restaurant on the patio and food was very good but service was excruciatingly slow. We ate breakfast at the hotel as well. The buffet was very pricey but very good and the staff very attentive(on our 2nd visit they carved little fruit baskets to look like flowers to the delight of our little girls). Pool was uncrowded and had a few pool toys which was a nice touch. Valet staff were very friendly and helpful.
reviews.title: Charming and historic

As a president's club member, we got a meal allowance and free parking. We heard the Indy race was in town and Anson at the Concierge desk was VERY helpful in getting us tickets with great last minute seats.

reviews.title: Avoid the street side and be prepared to pay a lot for food

reviews.text: Located on top of a hill in downtown Edmonton, the Hotel MacDonald, affectionately known as the Mac, combines historical charm and top notch service. Built in 1915, it's definitely not a modern hotel but the renovations make it the best stay in town. Some noice during the day due to current sixth floor renovations but the great food and comfortable oak bar make up for it.
reviews.title: Great old hotel

reviews.text: Having stayed at many Fairmont properties throughout North America the MacDonald is one of the worst. The location on Jasper Avenue although close to downtown is very difficult to get in and out of. I booked a executive king suite that has a rack rate of 700 dollars! Yes seven hundred bucks. I used a Presidents Club upgrade coupon to cut my costs to 369 plus 28 dollars for parking.
reviews.title: Overpriced, poorly located and generally mediocre.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Over 400 dollars a night in Edmonton! For that I got a 500 square foot room with ONE window. The bedroom alcove was like a dark cave. When I arrived at the Presidents Club check-in the woman was engaged in a lengthy telephone conversation that lasted ten minutes. There was no one else at the front counter. There was also no valet in sight when I pulled in. The reason that Fairmont gets away with charging ridiculous prices for a marginal hotel is that there really isn't any other "luxury" option in Edmonton and they take full advantage. Next time it's back to the Sutton Place for 150 bucks a night.
